section.title: Verbs + infinitive/-ing form
section.sectiontitle: When another verb follows like, love, enjoy, hate, can't stand we usually use the -ing form of the second verb.
section.text1a: We really enjoy visiting cities in other countries.
section.text2a: I can't stand getting up early in the morning.
section.sectiontitle2: It is possible to use the infinitive after like, love and hate. This is more common in American English.
section.text3a: I love to spend time with my niece and nephew.
section.text4a: We like to visit our friends at the weekend.

section.title: Verbs + infinitive/-ing form
section.sectiontitle: Use to + verb after would (not) like to express a desire for something in the future.
section.text1a: I would like to buy a bigger house.
section.text2a: They would really like to go to the opera, but they can't afford the tickets.
section.sectiontitle2: We usually use the contracted forms 'd like and wouldn't like.
section.text3a: I'd like to visit the Caribbean next year.
section.text4a: Laura wouldn't like to be a housewife. She enjoys working in an office.

section.title: Verbs + infinitive/-ing form
section.sectiontitle: Notice the difference between like + -ing form and would like + to + infinitive.
section.text1: Jessica plays the guitar and she enjoys it.
section.text2: Jessica doesn't play in a band but she wants to.
section.text2a: Jessica would like to play in a band.
